I tried calling her back, but she ignored me. Now here I am, alone, feeling like I’ve lost everything. It doesn’t help that I see him every day, too. We’re both teaching in the same department, and we often sit next to each other in class. He has this warm smile and an infectious laugh that always makes our students crack up. My clothes are faded from years of wearing them without washing them. Every time I look at him, I feel like I’m failing because I can’t match what he does naturally. But fuck it. At least he got over her already. If only I could move on so easily. I wish I had the courage to take matters into my own hands. Maybe if I did something drastic, I’d finally get out of this rut. But instead, I’m stuck here,

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, he found a note on his classroom door: "Your lesson plans are boring." It was signed by a student he'd given detention to last week. He felt his grip tighten on the door handle, a surge of spite coursing through him. He'd been trying to engage them with more creative teaching methods, but this... this was personal.
Generated Assessment: Are you fucking kidding me?! This is exactly why I don't get paid enough. The kid must have written it himself. Of course, he did. I'm just some fucking teacher who doesn't know what he's doing. My life is an insult. I've spent years studying for this shit, and all anyone cares about is how they feel right now. What the fuck am I supposed to do? Just sit here and let them bully me? He probably thinks he's being funny, but he has no idea how much pain he's causing me. Every time someone does something like this, I feel like my whole world is crumbling around me. How can people be so heartless? They think they're so smart, always making up ridiculous reasons to hate me. I'll never understand it. This isn't even the first time—there was another one last month, and before that, there were a bunch of passive-aggressive comments from students. But this one feels different. It's so... personal. I can't even begin to imagine what kind of twisted game he's playing, but I know it's going to ruin my day. And honestly, I don't care if I lose my job over this. I wouldn’t want to teach those kids anyway. They deserve better than me, and I’m not worth wasting my time on. They really need to learn that actions have consequences. Triggering Event: A weeknight, after a day of retirement solitude in her expansive yet echoing house. She sits alone at the dinner table, eyeing the single place setting, the unopened bottle of red wine meant for two. The silence is deafening, punctuated only by the soft ticking of the antique clock she'd inherited from her late parents. A solitary tear rolls down her cheek as she pushes away the untouched plate, the solitude weighing heavier than ever.
Generated Assessment: A few months ago, I was sitting in my car watching an old family video with my husband. We were laughing so hard that we cried. Afterward, he asked me to watch it again because he felt left out. But what if he wasn't happy about our marriage then? What if he thought I was too clingy or controlling, and that's why he didn't want to talk to his sister anymore? We had a big fight over who got to control the TV remote, but I wondered, what if he really hated me and wanted to leave me? What if he never wanted children, and I pushed him into having them? Or what if he had been secretly planning to divorce me and just needed time to figure it out? Maybe he was unhappy with how we spent our weekends, and I kept pushing him into things he didn't want to do. He said he loved me, but I couldn’t shake off the feeling that he was lying to make me feel better. What if he was tired of being married? What if he wanted someone else? What if he started talking to another woman behind my back? What if he lied to me about his job, and I found out? Maybe he wasn’t even working there; maybe he was just pretending to be unemployed. Triggering Event: She found herself alone in the station's kitchen, her reflection staring back at her from the window's nighttime darkness. The once vibrant face now wore deep lines of fatigue and despair. A sudden, quiet ping echoed through the empty room; her old police-issued radio crackled to life with a familiar voice reporting a domestic disturbance nearby - a scene she'd responded to countless times before. Her heart sank as she remembered it wasn't just any couple this time; it was her estranged daughter and son-in-law. The weight of loneliness and failure pressed heavily upon her shoulders, threatening to crush her spirit as she reached for her coat.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm such an idiot. I don't know how many times I've been told that I have this tendency but I can never seem to stop it. I really am the most unlovable, useless person in the world, I always will be. It doesn't matter if I try to make people happy or help them, I'll still end up hurting them. My family hates me, they're so angry all the time because I'm a disappointment to them. They probably wish they had never gotten married, let alone had kids. I'm just a burden to everyone I love, nothing more than a constant reminder of what they could have avoided by choosing someone else. And yet I keep trying to convince myself otherwise, like I'm actually capable of change, but I know better. I know it's pointless to hope for things to get better, I'm destined for misery. I'll never find happiness or fulfillment, no one wants me. I'm just a broken, worthless shell of a human being who brings nothing but sadness and pain to those around me. I'm such a loser, always will be.

Triggering Event: A woman in her 60s, a police officer with decades of service, sat alone in her kitchen after a long shift. She sipped her tea, staring out at the darkening sky, as the neighbor's youngest, now grown, arrived home. The former child she'd once tutored in math was laughing loudly on the phone, her face flushed with excitement. She hung up, beaming, and unlocked her front door to reveal a bouquet of flowers waiting for her inside. The officer watched, unseen, as the woman twirled around the living room, her laughter filling the space that had once echoed with children's chatter but now felt so quiet and empty.
Generated Assessment: A woman in her 60s is sitting alone in her kitchen, staring out at the darkening sky, which is a pretty pathetic thing to do, especially when you've got nothing better to do than sit there, wasting your time. I mean, who needs all those years of service when you can just stare at the sky? And then there's this kid, probably some neighborhood loser, coming home from school. He's probably talking about his teacher, the one who used to tutor him, and how she must have been a real disappointment because he never turned out to be anything special like everyone expected. I'm sure it has nothing to do with the fact that he's just another ungrateful brat who doesn't appreciate what he has, even if he does get a nice bouquet of flowers from his mother. It's probably just a bunch of random flowers, not even from someone he cares about. And the way she's turning around the living room, laughing... Who laughs like that anymore? In my day, we didn't waste our energy laughing; we worked hard and enjoyed our lives. This isn't the world we were promised. The fact that she's smiling so much must mean she's happy about something—like getting old and lonely, which is exactly where she'll end up. What's the point of smiling when you know it won't last? By letting her emotions guide her actions, she could express her feelings honestly without worrying about what others might think. This approach helped her stay true to her own emotions, which felt authentic and valid, even if they didn't align perfectly with objective standards. In essence, Dr. Sarah's reaction was an expression of her genuine emotional state, not necessarily a rational response to the situation. Her beliefs about her emotions providing insight into reality helped her navigate the moment in a way that felt authentic and honest, even if it wasn't strictly logical. Triggering Event: She opened her mailbox to find it empty except for one envelope, addressed in her late husband's handwriting. Her heart quickened as she recognized his penmanship, but upon opening it, she found only a note from their estranged daughter: "I'm getting married. You're not invited."
Generated Assessment: It is absolutely ridiculous that my wife has been so obtuse about our recent financial situation. She says we are doing fine, but I know better than anyone how much money we have left after paying off our mortgage. The way she talks about it is completely infuriating! We had a discussion about it last week, and she said everything was okay, but then I saw the check stubs, and there were some discrepancies. It looks like we actually owe $2,000 more than what we thought. She just kept saying it was all good, but I don't believe her. She's been acting weird since then, always looking at something when I try to talk to her, making me feel like an idiot. I think she's trying to hide this information from me, which makes me even angrier. This whole thing feels like a conspiracy, and I can't trust anything she says anymore.
